Title: Automatic Remediation of Kubernetes Nodes
Description: In Cloudflare’s core data centers, we are using Kubernetes to run many of the diverse services that help us control Cloudflare’s edge. We are automating some aspects of node remediation to keep the Kubernetes clusters healthy.

Title: Using Cosmos DB as an ASP.NET session state and caching provider
Description: Session state is widely used in web applications to store non-sensitive data related to user activity within the browser. ASP.NET Core has support for storing session state data across multiple providers like Redis and SQL Server. In this post, you’ll learn how to use the Azure Cosmos DB session and cache provider to leverage its low latency and global scale capabilities within your application.

Title: Directory.Build.props: C# 9 for all your projects | I CAN MAKE THIS WORK
Description: .NET Core can make use of C# 9 by making some changes to your .csproj files. There is a way to opt all projects in a solution into this behaviour in a single place, through using a Directory.Build.props file and / or a Directory.Build.targets file. Here's how to do it.

Title: Pa(dding rtitioning) oracles, and another hot take on PAKEs
Description: I’ve been trying to read more applied crypto papers here and there, and this past week, Partitioning Oracle Attacks (Len, Grubbs, Ristenpart) came up on my reading list. This paper presents a new class of attack against certain cryptographic protocols that are based on low-entropy secrets (e.g., passwords). It’s a way to dramatically speed up guessing attacks – for example, in some cases the attack allows the attacker to binary-search over a dictionary of passwords instead of trying them one-by-one. This type of attack seems likely to become a classic because it applies to some well-known encryption schemes and many different applications.

Title: Germany Fines YouTube Six Figures for Removing Video of Anti-Lockdown Protest

Title: Windows Terminal Preview 1.10 Release

Windows Terminal will include all of the features listed in the 1.9 blog post except for the default terminal setting and the ability to edit actions using the settings UI.

Title: The unreasonable effectiveness of just showing up everyday
Description:
When I first started working on Typesense six years ago, I set myself a simple rule:
 I shall write some code everyday before or after work.
 That’s it. No deadlines, no quarterly goals, no milestones.
I did not have a choice really — I was about to get married and was already working full-time in a demanding role. As you can imagine, building a search engine from scratch is not a trivial undertaking, so that was my way of not having to deal with additional stress.
